SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Charles George Pickard
Address: Fertile, Sask.
Birthplace: Brandon, Manitoba.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1901
Where did you set up housekeeping? At Roston, Manitoba
Where had you been living before that? At Findlay, Manitoba, at home
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4 men, boarding with us working for C.P.R.
How far was it to your nearest store? We lived in Roston, a very small place at that time.
How often could a visit be made to the store?
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Meat, flour, tea, coffee, yeast cakes, eggs, dried fruits, apples, baking powder, baking soda, butter, numerous other things. Had to buy everything while living in Roston.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS After moving out to the Prairies in 1904

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Harwood, Queen
First year bought flour after that got our wheat ground at the mill.
In what quantities did you buy it? Bought several bags so as always to have flour on hand.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? Around $1.50 per bag.
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? At Roston How far away? 16 miles What year? 1905
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Around 75¢
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, used some Whole Wheat, Farina
Other? Mace Johnny cake
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Some times would grind some to have a change from rolled oats
How did you grind it? Had a little grinder

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Curried meat, pork, venison, beef, and game.

How did you get fresh meat? Usually when we killed a pig or beef in the winter time.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? Made a brine in a barrel in the cellar and packed the barrel in it.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not until later years.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Not so much, could only get it in the winter time.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh fish, frozen.

Kinds? Pike, fish from the lakes.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

This is put up in brown paper or cardboard, also coffee in lined paper containers by local manufacturers.

Also dried fruits in packages. Meat all foods comes wrapped or in containers in just half as much room.

Sanitary than years before.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Our menu for breakfast was porridge with milk + sugar. Bread toasted on the stove with butter + a boiled egg in the summer. In winter, didn't have the eggs.

For dinner, baked pork, baked beans, fried potatoes + some vegetables. If we had it from the garden, cooked made with eggs + milk or bread pudding. In the winter, usually tried to have fresh meat.

For supper, warmed up potatoes, eggs + fried or boiled + what ever fruit we had picked + canned.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Roast chicken, potatoes, pickles, one vegetable, bread + butter, a steamed butternut pudding with raisins in it.

Mrs. Pickard, myself + two small children, also a nephew + a young boy from Winnipeg who stayed the winter with us.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Always had enough to eat whatever we had sometimes not much variety.

Some times only bread + milk for supper. Would heat the milk in a pot + break the bread in them serve in these bowls with sugar because fond of this.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? In
the early days, the family would have had a special meal on Christmas Day.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally

Always had enough food while we had a normal family
Some temporarily (bread & milk) but never crowded, had to make do at
times.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today. Early days we grew good gardens & raised all we could because we had no money to buy with. Baked our own bread also catch when ever we had one canned our vegetables or fruits. Did not buy much more than tea & coffee. Raised more on our own hens than for a living. Today hardly a woman in this district keeps her own hens. If she does keep a cat or get a cat, may be treated to not grow so much garden can buy all vegetables in cans also canned fruits of all kinds. If this buy canned meat, kith, pork, canned pork or think in cans or go to the Butcher shop for meat. Hardly ever hear of anyone killing their own meat. Ship whatever animal they have to dispose of & then buy there meat in a much easier way. Hardly any farmer milks a cow buys bottled milk or in cans.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We have never relied much on prepared foods. Have our little garden & prefer our own food as much as possible. Since the 30's we have had fairly good crops in this district & many now seem to rely on purchased foods. Prepared foods rather than home prepared foods.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Our Menu for Breakfast was Porridge with milk + sugar. Bread toasted on the stove with Butter.

For Dinner in Summer, Salt Pork, Potatoes + some vegetables if we had it from the garden. Custard made with eggs + milk or Bread Pudding. For the winter usually tried to have fresh meat. For supper warmed up Potatoes, eggs fried or baked + whatever fruit we had Pickled or canned.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Roast chicken, Potatoes, Pie + one vegetable. Bread + Butter + Steamed Sweet Raisin Pudding with raisins in it.

Mr. Pickard, my self + two children also a nephew, a young boy from Winnipeg who stayed the winter with us.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Always had enough to eat what ever we had sometimes not much variety. Sometimes only Bread + milk for supper. Would heat the milk in the pot, break the bread in, then serve in thin bowls with sugar. We were fond of this.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the past and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Our house in Bradfield was very small. We had a small living room, a dining room, a kitchen, and two bedrooms. The bedrooms were very small, and we often had to sleep on the floor.

For dinner, we would have roast beef, potatoes, and vegetables. For supper, we would have fish and chips.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give details.

I served my first Christmas dinner in Western Canada in 1945. It was a very special occasion because it was the first time I had ever cooked for someone else.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

I always had enough to eat, but there were times when the quality was very poor. I remember one particular winter when the potatoes were very bad.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today. Early days we grew good gardens tried to produce all we could because we had no money to buy while baked our own bread also eggs when ever we had one, canned our vegetables & fruits. Did not buy much more than tea & coffee. Relied more on our own resources for a living.

Today hardly a woman in this district lacks her garden. They can get a calf, pig & beef up. But nowadays much garden can buy at vegetables in cans also canned fruit of all kinds. After two canned meat. (Not afraid) canned pork & beans in cans go to the butcher shop for meat. Hardly ever lacks of any meat. Killing store own meat. Shipwreck ever arrived. They have to depend for them buy there meat in much easier way. Hardly any farmer needs a cow buys bottled milk or in cans.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible). We have never relied much on prepared foods have our little garden stills costs to prepare our own food as much as possible. Since the 30's we have had fairly good crops in this district & so many seem now to rely on purchased foods & prepared foods rather than home prepared foods.
